messageBody:
Quoth Scott Stirling:
[...]
> Put another way, I wonder the same thing about any behavior added to an
> object. Testing is not a behavior of most objects. So we should hope to
> test most objects without modeling testing in them in any way. So how do
> you make things testable without corrupting the object design with behaviors
> added or modified just to make objects testable? [...]

I gather from your comments that you consider it an important
principle of object-oriented development that a one-to-one (or
nearly one-to-one) correspondence between the objects being
modelled and the code objects used to model them is desirable. I
have a feeling (entirely unsupported by any knowledge of the
history of the field) that this principle might have arisen in the
context of the analysis and design of simulations, rather than
more general software development. It belongs to simulations,
imho, and is not very useful elsewhere.

For example, consider the model of concurrently executing
processes provided by multitasking operating systems, and in
particular the process and resource objects of such models.

Processes do not represent any real-world object; they are
entirely constructs of the model. The question of faithfulness of
representation doesn't arise.

Resources often do represent real-world objects, but it is highly
desirable that the representations have properties those objects
do not -- sharability among concurrently executing processes, for
example.

This illustrates a mode completely different from that of
simulation, one in which the greatest good of the model is
convenience for its clients (be they software or human), and
faithfulness of representation is, if not meaningless, of
marginal, zero, or even negative utility. In such modes, adding
behaviour to improve testability does not necessarily corrupt the
design. (Refactoring might be better, but adding might do.)

Adding such behaviour might even improve the design: testable code
is easier to change, not only because tests can tell you when your
changes have broken something, but also because testable code is
in general more modular. Changeability is imho the most desirable
property of code, and beats faithfulness of representation any
day. Fred Brooks writes that you should plan to throw one
implementation of your system away, since you will anyway. (It
might be said that the XP folk plan to throw away *every*
implementation.) This summarizes quite nicely my own experience,
which is that the code changes many times during development and
maintenance.
